issue.title: favicon?
issue.body: Do we have/need a favicon?

issue.title: xslt and styling changes
issue.body:
Several things off the bat:
- page heading should be up top instead of to the right; match BRP styling.
- Add a TOC for each page with links to the subheadings.
- Pull in <author> from tei header as in True and Candid
- add "Notes:" before the notes and make it the same size as a subheading, but don't put it in the TOC for the page.
- render tables and style them
- render blockquotes and style them
- rendering lists with no bullets by default, but bullets if it has a type=bulleted

issue.title: Literature module links
issue.body: Lots of off-site links to Internet Archive, Google Books, etc. This will have some structure, eg. be grouped by fiction, nonfiction, poetry, etc. Something prettier than lists would be great.

issue.title: model for person
issue.body:
Clicking on people in the family tree should take the user to a page like:

  /dusenbery/family/name/PERSONNAME

which should query the DB for all encoded documents matching PERSONNAME.

See Word docs in "P:\docsouth\Dusenbery\modules\Family". Links to individual objects should open a viewer like the main journal viewer. Everything has a page image and has been encoded.

issue.title: family module should be split into multiple pages
issue.body:
Probably true of all modules in terms of the length of the intro text. Have a "read more" link.

A jquery expand so that the user doesn't get sent to another page is probably a nice alternative to multiple pages.

issue.title: add pictures to Family and other modules pages.
issue.body:
"P:\docsouth\Dusenbery\photographs\images for intro pages"

Word document lists images for each intro. Captions are given for those that need captions. Note that some of the intros do not have entries in the navigation yet.

issue.title: transcription missing images
issue.body: The transcription doesn't contain pages 198 (inside back cover) and the back cover, even though there are images for these.

issue.title: determine optimal black/white cutoff with potrace
issue.body: potrace takes a -k option to set the black/white cutoff. Some pages may need a different value because they are other paper pasted into the journal... document in the wiki what pages need what, what values had what effect.

issue.title: Upgrade OpenLayers
issue.body: The latest version of OpenLayers is 2.7.  img2xml's viewer will need to be refactored to use it, and to accommodate future upgrades.

name: gameboy4iphone
description: A Nintendo Gameboy and Gameboy Color emulator for the Apple iPhone and iPod Touch.
readme:
GNUBOY README


  INTRO

Welcome to gnuboy, one of the few pieces of Free Software to emulate
the Game Boy handheld game console. Written in ANSI C with a few
optional assembler optimizations for particular cpus, gnuboy supports
a wide range of host systems, and has been tested successfully on:

  GNU/Linux
  FreeBSD
  OpenBSD
  BeOS
  Linux/390 (IBM S/390 Mainframe)
  SunOS/Sun Ultra60
  IRIX/SGI O2
  IRIX/SGI Indy
  AIX/Unknown
  DR-DOS
  MS-DOS
  Windows DOS box
  Windows 9x/NT/2k

Additionally, gnuboy should run on any other *nix variants that have
ANSI C compilers and that are remotely POSIX compliant. As gnuboy is
Free Software, you're welcome to fix any problems you encounter
building it for a particular system, or to port it to entirely new
systems.


  EMULATION

gnuboy emulates nearly all aspects of the (Color) Gameboy, including
all of the following and much more:

  Full GBZ80 instruction set.
  Scanline-based LCD engine.
  Ten sprites per scanline limit.
  Support for all CGB graphics extensions.
  Sprite DMA, HDMA, and GDMA.
  All four sound channels including digital samples.
  MBC1, MBC2, MBC3 (including clock), and MBC5 mappers.
  Wave pattern memory corruption when sound channel 3 is played.
  Pad, timer, divide counter, and other basic hardware registers.
  CGB double-speed CPU mode.

Aspects not emulated at this time include:

* Serial IO (link cable).
  Undocumented 'extra' ram in OAM space on Gameboy Color.
  All Super Gameboy extensions.
* GBC, HuC1, and HuC3 IR ports.
* Obscure mappers such as TAMA5.
  Sorting sprites by X coordinate in DMG mode.
  HALT instruction skipping in DMG mode.
  CPU stalls during HDMA and GDMA.

Only the two marked by * are known to affect the playability of
actual games or demos; the rest are just listed for completeness'
sake.


  FEATURES

In addition to basic emulation, gnuboy provides the following
features:

  Highly flexible keybinding and configuration subsystem.
  State saving and loading at any point.
  Very precise timing/synchronization, preserved across save/load.
  Joystick support on Linux, DOS, and all SDL-based ports.
  Fully customizable palettes for DMG games.
  Screen scaling by a factor of 2, 3, or 4 in all ports.
  Hardware-based screen scaling on platforms where it's available.
  Debug traces to stdout.
  Dynamic palette allocation when run in 256-color modes...
  OR simulated 3/3/2 bits per channel in 256-color modes.

For information on configuring and using these features, see the
additional documentation in the "docs" directory.


  COMPATIBILITY

Out of over 300 results reported by testers, all games are known to
work perfectly on gnuboy with the following exceptions:

  Fighting Phoenix (Japanese) may or may not work since it uses the
  HuC1 memory controller, which is not implemented properly. There has
  been no report either way so far.

  Pocket Bomberman (Japanese version, which uses HuC1) runs, but can
  be made to crash if the player jumps into the ceiling in the first
  level. It's not clear whether this bug is MBC-related, something
  else, or an actual bug in the original game.

  Monster Go! Go! Go! (Japanese) is unplayable. The cause of the
  problem is not fully known, but it's either a very bad dump or it's
  using some sort of specialized MBC that's not documented.

  Final Fantasy Adventure has visual problems with the fade between
  screens. Does not affect gameplay.

  Bubble Bobble 2 has some minor tile glitches right before gameplay
  actually begins. Cause unknown. Does not affect gameplay.

  Alone in the Dark is reported to have minor visual glitches. I
  haven't seen it myself so I can't judge their severity.

  Both new Zelda games are reported to have a visual glitch at the
  beginning of the game, and on certain other screens. I haven't seen
  the problem myself, but supposedly it impacts gameplay to some
  extent.

Please report any other incompatibilities discovered directly to
gnuboy@unix-fu.org, so that they can be documented and hopefully
fixed.


  FUTURE / WISHLIST

Here's a brief list of what may appear in gnuboy in the future:

  Screenshots.
  Integrated debugger.
  Super Gameboy support.
  Serial link over the internet.
  Serial link to a real Gameboy with a custom cable.
  Configurable color filters to provide more authentic LCD look.
  Custom colorization of DMG games on a per-tile basis.
  Support for more colorspaces in the hardware scaler.
  Recording audio.
  GBS player built from the same source tree.
  Full recording and playback of emulation.
  So-called "high level emulation" of certain typical dumb loops.

Features that are not likely to appear soon or at all include:

  Rumble support - this would be nice, but SDL doesn't seem to support
  force-feedback yet. We'll see about it in the long-term though.

  Eagle/2xSaI/etc. - probably not feasible since these libraries don't
  appear to be compatible with the terms of the GPL. We might work on
  our own interpolation engine eventually, but that's low priority.

  GUI/GUI-like features - such things are best handled by external
  front-ends. We might eventually add a mechanism for external
  programs to communicate with gnuboy and reconfigure it while it's
  running, however.

  Plugins - NO! The way I see it, plugins are just an attempt to work
  around the GPL. In any case, even if you are adding plugin support
  yourself, you are bound by the terms of the GPL when linking ANY
  code to gnuboy, including dynamic-linked modules. However we'd
  rather not deal with this mess to begin with.

  Compressed ROMs/Saves - this one is very iffy. On most systems, this
  is redundant; *nix users can just pipe the rom through a
  decompression program, and Windows users can just double-click or
  drag files from their favorite GUI unzipper program. Linking to zlib
  isn't really acceptable since it's massively bloated and we don't
  want to include it with gnuboy or add external dependencies. We may,
  however, write our own tiny decompressor to use at some point.

Ideas and suggestions for other features are welcome, but won't
necessarily be used. You're of course also free to add features
yourself, and if they fit well into the main tree they may eventually
get included in the official release. See the file HACKING for more
details on modifying and/or contributing.


  THANKS

Thanks goes out to everyone who's expressed interest in gnuboy by
writing -- users, porters, authors of other emulators, and so forth.
Apologies if we don't get a personal response out to everyone, but
either way, consider your feedback appreciated.


  EPILOGUE

OK, that looks like about it. More to come, stick around...



                                          -Laguna  <laguna@aerifal.cx>

commit.message:
Check that env variables are set first.

 * Python raises KeyError when you try to retrieve a non-existing key
   from dictionary. With my Ruby habits, I was expecting None to be
   returned. However, issue should be handled explicitly anyway.

Use environment variables instead of hardcoded paths

 * Makes it easier to use by other people

 * Makes it easier to use multiple copies of Nginx (say, a stable build,
   an edge build and a build with a module you are working on)
Rename restart command to reload because this is what Nginx really does.
Initial commit: Nginx ctl primarily useable on Mac.

name: deprec
description: master respository for deprec - deployment recipes for capistrano
readme:
------------------------------------------
deprec - Deployment Recipes for Capistrano
------------------------------------------

== Introduction

The deprec [1] gem is a set of tasks for Capistrano [2]. These tasks provide
for the installation, configuration and control of system services. Deprec 
was created in 2006 by Mike Bailey to setup an environment for running Ruby 
on Rails web applications on Ubuntu dapper servers. Since then its uses have
grown to installing mail, monitoring, high availability IP failover and other 
services.

The tasks are run at the command line on your workstation and connect to 
remote servers via ssh to run commands and copy out files.

Deprec-2.x is a complete rewrite of the project that achieves the following:

- support for Capistrano 2
- support for more services (heartbeat, nagios, nginx, ntp, postfix, etc) 
- creation of a standard base set of task names
- tasks are cleanly separated into namespaced units (one file per service)
- service config files are stored locally to enable edits and version control
- interactive prompting for missing config values

One idea that is in the trash can is supporting other distros/OS's. While I got
caught up in the excitement of The Big Rewrite I've decided I don't need it. If 
you want to deploy to something other than Ubuntu I suggest you look for other 
alternatives.

Deprec and Capistrano are written in the Ruby programming language [3] however 
no knowledge of Ruby is required to use it. Users should be able to write 
new tasks and modify existing options without prior knowledge of Ruby.


== Installation

Deprec can be obtained from rubyforge[4] and installed using rubygems[5].

	sudo gem install deprec  # installs deprec and dependancies 
	cap depify .			 # creates ~/.caprc which you may edit
	cap -T					 # should list lots of deprec tasks

The .caprc file is loaded every time you use Capistrano. It in turn loads 
the deprec tasks so you always have them available. Editing the .caprc file 
in your home directory allows you to specify the location of your ssh key
and enable some other useful options (documented in the comments). You can
also put tasks here that you want to always have access to.


== Getting a Ruby on Rails app running on a fresh Ubuntu server

This is still what brings people to deprec. You can install a full Rails stack
and get multiple apps running on it in much less time than it would take to 
do it manually. Think an hour vs. a weekend. (The irony is I'm up writing this
on a Saturday night.)

	export HOSTS=<target.host.name>

	# Install Rails stack
	cap deprec:rails:install_rails_stack

	# Install mysql (if it's running on the same box)
	cap deprec:mysql:install
	cap deprec:mysql:config_gen
	cap deprec:mysql:config

	# Install your Rails app
	cap deploy:setup
	cap deploy
	cap deprec:db:create
	cap deprec:db:migrate
	cap deprec:nginx:restart
	cap deprec:mongrel:restart

You can find documentation on the deprec site. http://www.deprec.org/


== Installing other things

I plan to document other things I use deprec for on http://www.deprec.org/. 
Feel free to poke around and see what's there. I use deprec to provision and 
manage servers so you might find some things in there I haven't documented. Lucky you.


== Disclaimer

The tasks run commands that may make changes to your workstation and remote server. 
You are advised to read the source and use at your own risk.


== Credits

Deprec is written and maintained by Mike Bailey <mike@bailey.net.au>. 
More about me here: [http://mike.bailey.net.au/]

Deprec was inspired and uses the brilliantly executed Capistrano. Thanks Jamis!
This gem includes a modified copy of Neil Wilson's very useful vmbuilder_plugins gem.


== Thanks

Eric Harris-Braun: great testing, bug reports and suggestions

commit.message:
Added recipes and templates for setting up an apt mirror.

If you're installing a lot of ubuntu instances you can save
some bandwidth by using a local mirror to install and update
from.

The problem (for us bandwidth deprived Aussies at least) is
that a mirror can easily be 45GB. This would cost $450 to
download at our datacentre. I downloaded using a home ADSL
connection and took it to the datacentre on a USB drive.

It's super fast to install extra packages now from my local
apt-mirror. It syncs up each night.

Restricted tasks to roles.

I like restricting tasks to roles, partly out of laziness. I don't need
to specify HOSTS or ROLES on the command line as long as I've defined
the relevant roles somewhere. It also provides a safety net. Without
specifying HOSTS or ROLES on the command line, a task will get run on
*all* defined hosts. This can be avoided by restricting the tasks
themselves in deprec.

A problem with restricting tasks to roles in deprec was that Capistrano
complained when I ran a task in an ad-hoc manner without any hosts being
defined for the roles it was restricted to.

Sometimes I want to run a task on hosts but don't want to add them to
a deploy.rb. Editing a file just to use a command line is extra work!

e.g. cap deprec:mysql:install HOSTS=foo,bar

This problem caused me to remove a lot of role restrictions from deprec
over the last year or so.

My Capistrano patch (included in capistrano-2.5.0) causes Capistrano
to not complain about an undefined role if HOSTS or ROLES are specified
on the command line.

http://github.com/jamis/capistrano/commit/8badb0c522b38fae9cbe973451472afbddef61cb

So, I'm putting the roles back in.

- Mike

* Restricted all tasks to :role => :aoe
* Updated packages
* Put in values to override :setup_defaults task in capistrano_extensions
added dnsutils, provider of 'dig' (among other things)
reload postfix after pushing out configs
How do you diff your changes after doing a 'git add'???

We now setup a satellite mail server. This is designed to listen
only on the local network interface and non-local mail to a relay
host.
Merge branch 'update_rubygem_src_package' of git://github.com/jasherai/deprec into jasherai

for_roles() now only sets ROLES if HOSTS has not been specified
on command line. The is in keeping with Capistrano which uses
overrides role specification if HOSTS is set.
Moved helper task out of the way as it's not called by any deprec tasks

Add configure and make options to src_package for rubygems to override later
setting of defaults.
Use :rails_env rather then 'production' when rotating rails log file.
Upgrade to rubygems 1.2.0 - addresses memory utilization issues on low-memory boxes (half-gig or less)
Replaced hard coded path with shared_path variable
Replaced hard coded path with shared_path variable
notes on using vnstat with xen
iweb page to display vnstat totals
vnstat recipes - measure and report traffic on interface counters
added vnstat for counting traffic on interfaces
don't restrict mysql recipes to mysql role
bugfix: config_gen task shoudl not call config
Correctly handle with tarballs with .tgz extension
Generate default remote config on install

Removed some tasks that are better provided by gitosis
Updated deprec:git:create_remote_origin
install_stack no longer generates system level local config files
You can now install hardy domU on a gutsy dom0
unlock git account so we can actually use it!

DRY'ed up source package definitions a bit.
Generate remote system level configs for (most) services on install.
new default path to apps is /opt/apps

added method "for_roles" which accepts one or more roles
and a block to be run for those roles.

* added 'git' to install_rails_stack
* added task :install_rails_stack_no_config
  - toying with the idea that a default config should be
    installed during installation and that config_gen & config
    should then called later. That was we can pre-install stacks
    without worrying about the config at that time.

* set nginx user and group back to 'nginx' as it failed to start
when set to 'nobody'
* switched to new brief src_package declaration

fix to deal with race condition should a file be pushed to
multiple hostnames that point to the same host
testing the new brief SRC_PACKAGE format
moved source package out of namespace declaration (for clarity)

added tasks to find URLs of source packages
Used this to pull together files for using deprec while offline

set_package_defaults method allows us to provide sparser source package
declarations

issue.title: Hi! I cleaned up your code for you!
issue.body:
Hi there!

This is WhitespaceBot. I'm an [open-source](https://github.com/Gunio/LightWrite) robot that removes trailing white space in your code, and gives you a gitignore file if you didn't have one!  

Why whitespace? Whitespace is an eyesore for developers who use text editors with dark themes. It's not  a huge deal, but it's a bit annoying if you use Vim in a terminal. Really, I'm just a proof of  concept - GitHub's V3 API allows robots to automatically improve open source projects, and that's really cool. Hopefully, somebody, maybe you!, will fork me and make me even more useful. My owner is [funding a bounty](http://gun.io/open/12/add-security-flaw-fixing-features-to-whitespacebot) to anybody who can add security fixing features to me. 

I've only cleaned your most popular project, and I've added you to a list of users not to contact again, so you won't get any more pull requests from me unless you ask. If I'm misbehaving, please email my owner and tell him to turn me off! If this is pull request is of no use to you, please just ignore it.

Thanks!
WhiteSpacebot from [Gun.io](http://gun.io).

name: ultrasphinx
description: Ruby on Rails configurator and client to the Sphinx full text search engine
readme:
Ultrasphinx 

Ruby on Rails configurator and client to the Sphinx full text search engine.

== License

Copyright 2007-2008 Cloudburst, LLC. Licensed under the AFL 3. See the included LICENSE file. Some portions copyright Pat Allan, distributed under the MIT license, and used with permission. Some portions copyright PJ Hyett and Mislav MarohniÄ‡, distributed under the MIT license, and used with permission. 

The public certificate for the gem is here[http://rubyforge.org/frs/download.php/25331/evan_weaver-original-public_cert.pem]. 

If you use this software, please {make a donation}[http://blog.evanweaver.com/donate/], or {recommend Evan}[http://www.workingwithrails.com/person/7739-evan-weaver] at Working with Rails.

== Requirements

* MySQL 5.0, or PostgreSQL 8.2
* Sphinx 0.9.8-rc2
* Rails 2.0.2

More recent versions than listed are usually ok.

== Features

Sphinx/Ultrasphinx is the fastest and most stable Rails fulltext search solution.

Features include:

* searching and ranking across multiple models
* delta index support
* excerpt highlighting
* Google-style query parser
* spellcheck
* faceting on text, date, and numeric fields
* field weighting, merging, and aliasing
* geodistance
* <tt>belongs_to</tt> and <tt>has_many</tt> includes
* drop-in compatibility with will_paginate[http://err.lighthouseapp.com/projects/466/home]
* drop-in compatibility with Interlock[http://blog.evanweaver.com/files/doc/fauna/interlock/]
* multiple deployment environments
* comprehensive Rake tasks

And some other things.

= Usage

== Installation
  
First, install Sphinx itself. Get the {0.9.8 snapshot}[http://www.sphinxsearch.com/downloads.html], then run <tt>./configure</tt>, <tt>make</tt>, and <tt>sudo make install</tt>. Make sure to set your <tt>./configure</tt> flags: <tt>----prefix</tt> if necessary, and also <tt>----with-pgsql</tt> if you need Postgres support.

You also need the <tt>chronic</tt> gem:
  sudo gem install chronic

Then, install the plugin:
  script/plugin install git://github.com/fauna/ultrasphinx.git
 
Next, copy the <tt>examples/default.base</tt> file to <tt>RAILS_ROOT/config/ultrasphinx/default.base</tt>. This file sets up the  Sphinx daemon options such as port, host, and index location.
  
If you need per-environment configuration, you can use <tt>RAILS_ROOT/config/ultrasphinx/development.base</tt>, etc. Note that ERb is also allowed within the <tt>.base</tt> files, and can be an alternative way to DRY up multiple configurations.

Now, in your models, use the <tt>is_indexed</tt> method to configure a model as searchable. For example:
  
  class Post
    is_indexed :fields => ['created_at', 'title', 'body']
  end
  
For more index options, see ActiveRecord::Base .is_indexed.

== Building the index

Now run:

  rake ultrasphinx:configure
  rake ultrasphinx:index
  rake ultrasphinx:daemon:start

To rotate the index, just rerun <tt>rake ultrasphinx:index</tt>. If the search daemon is running, it will have its index rotated live. Otherwise the new index will be installed but the daemon will remain stopped.

== Running queries
    
Query the daemon as so:

  @search = Ultrasphinx::Search.new(:query => @query)
  @search.run
  @search.results
  
For more query options, including excerpt mode, see Ultrasphinx::Search.
  
= Extras  

== Pagination

Once the <tt>@search</tt> object has been <tt>run</tt>, it is directly compatible with the <tt>will_paginate</tt> view helper. In your view, just do:
  <%= will_paginate(@search) %>
  
== Spell checking

See Ultrasphinx::Spell.

== Delta indexing 

Delta indexing speeds up your updates by not reindexing the entire dataset every time. 

First, in your <tt>.base</tt> file, set the indexer option <tt>delta</tt> to your maximum interval between full reindexes. A day or a week is good, depending. Add a little bit to account for the time it takes the actual index to run:

  delta = <%= 1.day + 30.minutes %> 

Now, configure your models for delta indexing in the <tt>is_indexed</tt> call:

  is_indexed :fields => ['created_at', 'title', 'body'],
    :delta => true

Now you can run <tt>rake ultrasphinx:index:delta</tt> frequently, and only records that were changed within 1 day will be reindexed. You will need to run <tt>rake ultrasphinx:index:main</tt> once a day to move the delta contents into the main index.

See ActiveRecord::Base .is_indexed and DEPLOYMENT_NOTES[link:files/DEPLOYMENT_NOTES.html] for more.
  
== Available Rake tasks

See RAKE_TASKS[link:files/RAKE_TASKS.html].

== Deployment notes

See DEPLOYMENT_NOTES[link:files/DEPLOYMENT_NOTES.html].

== Gotchas

Note that since Ultrasphinx preloads indexed models, you need to make sure those models have their own dependencies in place early in the boot process. This may require adjusting the general plugin load order or moving monkey-patches from <tt>lib/</tt> to <tt>vendor/plugins/</tt>.

PostgreSQL 8.2 and higher are well supported. However, make sure the stored procedure migration gets generated correctly. If you did not install the plugin via <tt>script/install</tt>, run <tt>script/generate ultrasphinx_migration</tt> by hand.

== Reporting problems

The support forum is here[http://rubyforge.org/forum/forum.php?forum_id=14244].

Patches and contributions are very welcome. Please note that contributors are required to assign copyright for their additions to Cloudburst, LLC. 

== Further resources

* http://sphinxsearch.com/doc.html
* http://sphinxsearch.com/forum/forum.html?id=1
* http://blog.evanweaver.com/articles/2007/07/09/ultrasphinx-searching-the-world-in-231-seconds

name: typography
description: Simple rails plugin to make text more readable by applying some typographic rules to string.
readme:
==Typography

Simple plugin to make text more readable by applying some typographic rules to string. It is intended to use for russian texts, but some english typography rules are also supported.

==Example

This plugin adds .typography method for string:

	'"Ð§Ð¸Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑˆÑŒ -- "ÐŸÑ€Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð¿ÑŒÐµÐ² Ð»ÑŽÐ±Ð¸Ð» ÑÐ¾Ð»ÑÐ½ÐºÑƒ" -- Ð¸ Ð´Ð¾Ð»Ð³Ð¾ Ð½Ðµ Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑˆÑŒ Ð¿Ð¾Ð½ÑÑ‚ÑŒ, Ð¿Ð¾Ñ‡ÐµÐ¼Ñƒ ÑÐ¾Ð»ÑÐ½ÐºÐ° Ð½Ð°Ð¿Ð¸ÑÐ°Ð½Ð° Ñ Ð¼Ð°Ð»ÐµÐ½ÑŒÐºÐ¾Ð¹ Ð±ÑƒÐºÐ²Ñ‹, Ð²ÐµÐ´ÑŒ "Ð¡Ð¾Ð»ÑÐ½ÐºÐ°" -- Ð¸Ð·Ð²ÐµÑÑ‚Ð½Ñ‹Ð¹ Ð¼Ð¾ÑÐºÐ¾Ð²ÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ ÐºÐ»ÑƒÐ±."'.typography
	# => '«Ð§Ð¸Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑˆÑŒ — „ÐŸÑ€Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð¿ÑŒÐµÐ² Ð»ÑŽÐ±Ð¸Ð» ÑÐ¾Ð»ÑÐ½ÐºÑƒ“ — Ð¸ Ð´Ð¾Ð»Ð³Ð¾ Ð½Ðµ Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑˆÑŒ Ð¿Ð¾Ð½ÑÑ‚ÑŒ, Ð¿Ð¾Ñ‡ÐµÐ¼Ñƒ ÑÐ¾Ð»ÑÐ½ÐºÐ° Ð½Ð°Ð¿Ð¸ÑÐ°Ð½Ð° Ñ Ð¼Ð°Ð»ÐµÐ½ÑŒÐºÐ¾Ð¹ Ð±ÑƒÐºÐ²Ñ‹, Ð²ÐµÐ´ÑŒ „Ð¡Ð¾Ð»ÑÐ½ÐºÐ°“ — Ð¸Ð·Ð²ÐµÑÑ‚Ð½Ñ‹Ð¹ Ð¼Ð¾ÑÐºÐ¾Ð²ÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ ÐºÐ»ÑƒÐ±.»'

It is better to use ty helper in your views:

	ty 'This is a page title'
	# => 'This is a page title'

Plugin also replaces h and simple_format helpers to apply typography to their results.


==Installation

	script/plugin install git://github.com/varezhka/typography.git


Copyright (c) 2008 Igor Gladkoborodov, released under the MIT license

name: facebooker
description: The facebooker Rails plugin
readme:
Copyright (c) 2007 Chad Fowler, Patrick Ewing

= Facebooker

Facebooker is a Ruby wrapper over the Facebook[http://facebook.com] {REST API}[http://developer.facebook.com].  Its goals are:

* Idiomatic Ruby
* No dependencies outside of the Ruby standard library (This is true with Rails 2.1. Previous Rails versions require the JSON gem)
* Concrete classes and methods modeling the Facebook data, so it's easy for a Rubyist to understand what's available
* Well tested

= Installing (Non Rails)

The best way is:

  gem install facebooker

If, for some reason, you can't/won't use RubyGems, you can do:

  (sudo) ruby setup.rb

= Installing (Rails)

Facebooker can be installed as a Rails plugin by:

  script/plugin install git://github.com/mmangino/facebooker.git

If you don't have git, the plugin can be downloaded from http://github.com/mmangino/facebooker/tarball/master

Once the plugin is installed, you will need to configure your Facebook app in config/facebooker.yml. 

Your application users will need to have added the application in facebook to access all of facebooker's features. You enforce this by adding

  ensure_application_is_installed_by_facebook_user  

to your application controller.


== Work in Progress

I'm not saying it meets its goals fully yet.  Please help.  I'm especially interested in feedback and criticism re: Ruby style and design and testing.  RCov has the library (at the time of this writing) at 100% coverage.  I take that with a grain of salt, but it's a good start.

== Contribute

Please visit the {RubyForge project page}[http://rubyforge.org/projects/facebooker] to get the latest source via svn, write some tests, add/fix features, and submit a patch via the tracker.  If you submit a good patch, it's likely that I'll add you to the project for commit access if you want to be added.

commit.message:
Removed encodeURI from facebooker.js

Having it there made my code fail, and I couldn't see what it was needed for?
Is there concern that FB's serialize() isn't sanitized enough or...?

How it failed for me was using a form field such as 'name="posts[subject]"' as the Form.serialize saw posts and passed the object which contained subject (and another posts variable) and didn't know how to handle that.
Fixed tests to reflect new session handling
Use underscore instead of downcase in form builder, so class names with multiple words work.

This reverts commit b95be2a17796eead640de90680104f30ffb73bf9.

Use underscore instead of downcase in form builder, so class names with multiple words work.

Fixed SetStatus parser and added tests

http://rubyforge.org/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=20750&group_id=4187&atid=16130
Update notification to use new types that Facebook silently introduced
Merge changes from another app. Make batching threadsafe
Fix publisher to not use sessions where possible

* fix nil.new error when no exception found for a error code

* fix rails_integration test to use parsed json comparison instead of indeterministic json string comparison
in facebooker.js, encode uri components globally
Fixing target ids for the new publishUserAction they should not be a json encoded array but rather just a string of comma separated ids.

Facebooker::User#== compares Facebook IDs to determine equality.
Adding support for Profile Box on the main Profile page. This is done via the profile_main parameter to the setProfileFBML
Verify that facebook session_key is the same as the session key being posted via facebook_params
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/digidigo/facebooker into digidigo
Added protection_against_forgery to facebook_form_for and fb_multi_friend_request
Syncing with master friend list and fixing of publisher
Factoring out new api methods so that they can be overrided without ENV var
Added friend list support. Based heavily upon work by Brian Lee
Allow option to specify name in form builder

git-svn-id: svn+ssh://rubyforge.org/var/svn/facebooker/trunk/facebooker@64 06148572-b36b-44fe-9aa8-f68b04d8b080

This patch does the following 1) Overrides redirect_to in the controller so that if the request is from a facebook canvas
it renders an fbml redirect tag instead of issuing an actual redirect. Without this, if a user visits
apps.facebook.com/your_app/ and you require the user to be authenticated, a redirect to the login page will be issued.
Facebook will intercept the redirect and attempt to display it's login page in an fbml canvas which will result in an
error. 2) Allows login_url to take a list of options such as :canvas => true. Which tells facebook that you would
like your callback_url to be displayed in a facebook canvas after login is complete. 3) Allows you to set
default_login_url_options, so that you can set the :canvas => true option conveniently from a config file.


.....and later:

I'm attaching a better implementation of my previously submitted
patch. The
patch no longer has a Session.set_default_login_url_options,
and instead
creates a session subclass called CanvasSession that simply overrides
Session#default_login_url_options.

Additionally, I've added 
Controller#ensure_application_is_installed_by_facebook_user which
is a
useful before_filter for canvas apps that wish to require installation
by the
user.

comments.body:
Can anyone tell me what this might break?

-- also pretty new to github -- I thought I was being nice fixing the softtabs vs. tabs that were in the source file -- but the diff display seems to make it look wrong (though the raw display is right).  Is that normal?

Do you guys care about tabs/spaces in the source?
Excellent. Facebook had a bug at one point that caused this to be necessary. You've tested this well and it works for you? If so, I'll pull this in.

I've been running it @ http://apps.facebook.com/comicbooks/ for a couple of weeks (for 3 or 4 functions) and haven't seen any problems -- I didn't really run it  through too many cases but it's sending the params I'm expecting.

If you do pull you might not want to chop out encodeURIComponent though -- I can see how others might have made use of that function in their own code and getting rid of it might break that for them (I thought of this after of course).

name: mycpan-indexer
description: (Perl) Index a Perl distribution
readme:
=pod

=encoding utf8

=head1 The MyCPAN::Indexer module

This is the I<README> for the L<MyCPAN::Indexer> Perl module. You're probably 
looking at this because you don't know where else to find what you're
looking for. Read this once and you might never have to read one again 
for any Perl module.

=head2 Documentation

To read about L<MyCPAN::Indexer>, look at the embedded documentation 
in the module itself. Inside the distribution, you can format it 
with L<perldoc|http://perldoc.perl.org/perldoc.html>:

	% perldoc lib/MyCPAN/Indexer.pm

If you have already installed the module, you can specify the module
name instead of the file location:

	% perldoc MyCPAN::Indexer

You can read the documentation and inspect the meta data on one of the 
CPAN web interfaces, such as L<CPAN Search|http://search.cpan.org/dist/MyCPAN-Indexer> or 
L<MetaCPAN|http://www.metacpan.org/module/MyCPAN::Indexer>:

=over 4

=item *	L<http://search.cpan.org/dist/MyCPAN-Indexer>

=item *	L<http://www.metacpan.org/module/MyCPAN::Indexer>

=back

The standard module documentation has example uses in the SYNOPSIS
section, but you can also look in the I<examples/> directory (if it's
there), or look at the test files in I<t/>.

=head2 Installation

You can install this module with a CPAN client, which will resolve
and install the dependencies:

	% cpan MyCPAN::Indexer
	% cpanm MyCPAN::Indexer

You can also install directly from the distribution directory, which
will also install the dependencies:

	% cpan .
	% cpanm .

You could install just this module manually:

	% perl Makefile.PL
	% make
	% make test
	% make install

You probably don't want to do that unless you're fiddling with the 
module and only want to run the tests without installing anything.

=head2 Source location
	
The meta data, such as the source repository and bug tracker, is in
I<Makefile.PL> or the I<META.*> files it creates. You can find that on
those CPAN web interfaces, but you can also look at files directly in
the source repository:

=over 4

=item *	L<https://github.com/briandfoy/mycpan-indexer>

=back

If you find a problem, file a ticket in the L<issue 
tracker|https://github.com/briandfoy/mycpan-indexer/issues>:

=over 4

=item *	L<https://github.com/briandfoy/mycpan-indexer/issues>

=back

=head2 Getting help

Although I'm happy to hear from module users in private email,
that's the best way for me to forget to do something.

Besides the issue trackers, you can find help at
L<Perlmonks|http://www.perlmonks.org> or
L<Stackoverflow|http://www.stackoverflow.com>, both of which have many
competent Perlers who can answer your question, almost in real time.
They might not know the particulars of this module, but they can help
you diagnose your problem. 

You might like to read L<brian's Guide to Solving Any Perl 
Problem|http://archive.oreilly.com/pub/a/perl/excerpts/9780596527242/brians-guide.html>.

=head2 Copyright and License

You should have received a I<LICENSE> file, but the license is also noted
in the module files. About the only thing you can't do is pretend that
you wrote code that you didn't. 

=head2 Good luck!

Enjoy, 

brian d foy, bdfoy@cpan.org

=cut

commit.message:
Merge pull request #2 from haydenty/master

Added CONTRIBUTING.md
Make min Perl version in Travis match the minimum required version
Add v5.22 to Travis, and run in container by turning off sudo
Add v5.22 to Travis, and run in container by turning off sudo
Fix whitespace in YAML: tabs no longer allowed
Add Pod to all the Makefile.PLs
The new README.pod, fit for GitHub
It's not bugtraker with no c
Update LICENSE file to include full license
Most of the modernization of Makefile.PL
Die if we cannot load correct ExtUtils::MakeMaker
Fix changes.t for missing interpolated variable
Merge a version I never released
Add author test for Changes file
normalize Changes header line according to CPAN::Changes::Spec
Move BackPAN indexer to the right spot
Get the dist name to fix strict error
Skip Tk and Curses, for now
Check filenames in module paths to see what I can exclude
Find dists that unpack into their own directory
Delete stuff in inc/ and create index
Adjust die messages in optional interface modules
Various tools for dealing with YAML stuff
Adjust find_dist_dir to look for a module at the top level
Output progress info, write to file as UTF-8
Create the table only if it doesn't exist
BackPAN indexing doesn't care about zero dist files
Refactor the stuff to check for zero dist size
Find YAML files and dump them with YAML::XS
See which YAML reader can read the files
Convert YAML files to another dumper. YAML::XS wins
Try harder to kill children and re-sequence some code.
Use YAML::XS and try to handle all version strings.
A little reformatting. No big whoop.
Move those opening braces up a line
Match column names in md5 database match data file names
Don't put newlines in log messages; it's _Set_stash, with leading _
* Brian Cassidy fixed the %optional handling in Makefile.PL
* fix minor problems to get the tests to pass

Zero dist sizes are no longer fatal. That situation is caught in the
worker. That's not the best thing but that's where it is now.

display_value turns reference values into dumps for easier debugging,
although now the log messages can be very large.

Refactor all the unpacking stuff and clarify when an unpacking error
happens. Separate out the monkeypatching of the Extractor classes.

Work much harder to load a YAML file, especially when it might be
Latin-1.

Use YAML::Syck. Move the YAML monkeypatching out of the way.

Work harder to get the output of external commands. If the output is
very long, truncate it. Some things would output the same prompt
forever, making the output grow forever. Now we get those dists under
control by closing their filehandles.

* Get the existing report logic right (fewer negations)

I had too many nots and nos floating around, so I reduced some of those.
The queue now also reports some stats about how many dists it thinks it
needs to work on.

* Now have to hardcode the collator note key

The component type is now a bit field

* Make report path before opening the report file

Now that I'm not writing to a single directory, I have to ensure
that the subdirectories are there.
Change Carp calls to Log4perl calls
* In early setup before logging, remember some things to log later
The interface only calls the collater if it's a sub ref
The interface only calls the collater if it's a sub ref
* Handle a possible div by 0 in ShowDist
Rewrap some paras in Tutorial, and say more about the Collaborator

* Succeed for zero-byte dist files, add unindexable key

If a zero-byte distribution file (8 of them in BackPAN) don't unpack, that's
not realyl an error. It's a dist that we know that we can never index, so
mark it as such and succeed. It's no longer anything we have to track as
an error.
Add a method to remove stuck processes taking up memory; unused so far
A script to go through error reports and classify errors
Copy bad dists in a separate directory, for testing
A script to take a flat file of reports and put them into subdirs
* We have to log the perl later because we remember it so early

* Add docs, add post_setup_logging_items

+ After logging is set up, look in notes for things that
earlier methods wanted to log
* Note that set_note takes two arguments
* Can't call logging until we set up logging
* Adjust reporter test now that paths are hashed
* Adjust mock now that get_component is a coordinator object
* make this a composite type (the first one so far)
* Make composite component types, and represent them with bit fields
* Start hashing the report paths: A/AB/ABC-0.01.tgz
Check if a report exists before adding a dist to the queue
* Use IPC::Open3, fix a YAML override, some errors are now info
* Use Clone instead of Storable because I need to handle CODE refs
* Warn if I try to access a dist key that is not there
* Ignore the sub-projects/ directory for MANIFEST
* Add the stuff I used to test the forking lockups
* Adjust MANIFEST to keep out various research files
* Add the ending > on the default email address
* Replace the default indexer_id with my name until I fix up the reports
* various scripts to pull things out of indexing reports
* Extract stuff from the index for the DPAN extra_reports
* Lists of distros that I haven't been able to index properly
* Report that the output path is missing only after we created the file and written the data
* Use IPC::Open2 instead of backticks to run external commands
* Extract the MD5s for all the files in the distro
* The script to pull the MD5 digest out of the YAML files
* The script that iterates through @INC comparing MD5 digests
* Add a README to the MD5 examination of @INC stuff
* Start organizing the various backpan tasks into sub-projects
* rename get_md5 to get_md5_of_file_contents, which is what it is supposed to do

* Add PERL_MM_USE_DEFAULT and PERL_EXTUTILS_AUTOINSTALL variables to environment

   I can't assume that they are there like in my CPAN.pm config. :)
* Fix module name in docs, adjust copyright date
* Setup INT and WARN handlers after logging has be setup
* Get the MD5 of the file contents, not the file name\!

* Weaken reference to Coordinator in Component to get rid of the circular ref

This was the problem with Log4perl objects disappearing because
circular references make the clean-up order weird.

* Move the error catching and redefinitions until after logging setup

There's still a problem with the Log4perl object disappearing mysteriously
* That data really needs to be an object, but until then it's a hash
* Cheat on that undef return value by turning it into the empty string

* Move retry_errors checking to the worker from the indexer

This means that at the App level, we're not deleting the error
report directory if retry_errors is true. We want to keep those
around in case a Queue class wants to look at the errors to
choose some for re-indexing.
* check_for_previous_error_result returns the file basename in the true case
* Compile all built modules during the load test
* Don't include modules with missing optional dependencies
* Make the reporter before the queue so the queue can get a list of error reports
* Try to capture errors from YAML
* Just a whitespace fix around qw()

* Add new Queue components that selectively choose files

ErrorReports: only tries distros that hand previous errors
FromList: arbitrary list from users
NewFiles: only dists from so recent interval
* Add new Queue components and YAML dependency
* Trap YAML warnings when writing reports
* Put count in front of first line of +, and an elapsed time at the end of each line
* Refactor the child cleanup stuff and call at the end of the task just to be sure
* Clean up grandchildren in ALRM handler by walking process table
* Try to generate META.yml for dists that don't have one
* Show reports completed, total reports in each line of dots
* Better matching for PAUSE IDs, which might have a - or a number!
* Added a new indexer to collect file stats for BackPAN
* Made a null interface class that outputs nothing at all
* Moved TestCensus.pm into a subdirectory for Indexers
* Log when we don't find a META.yml
* Need to look in run info for errors
* Add a program to grep error messages from error reports
* Show the error for a bad index of a dist in ShowDist.pm
* Try returning a nice error message
* Add Imager module to dists that I need to handle
* use IPC::System::Simple, and actually skip error dists
* Added some debugging statements in Worker.pm before it kicks off the indexer.
* Return an Indexer object even if we skip the dist
* Show a status with each line of ShowDist output
* Add an interface component to print one line per dist
* Only set the fatal_error in examine_dist if the dist step said it was fatal
* Graffle files that show the process
* Bump version to sync with DPAN
* Fix MD5 code to avoid copying files, and move around some error messages to be less chatty
* Catch SIGINT and move out of temp dirs before exit so File::Temp can cleanup

* Fix merge_dirs to actually work

1. Don't define merge_dirs in the defaults or it messes up
checking to see if it is already defined

2. Arguments on the command line trump config files

3. I can't store references in ConfigReader::Simple, so that
sucks. I think I might need a subclass to do that. Now I
store it as strings joined with a null byte.
* Add merge dirs, and organize_dists copies instead of renames
* dpan now has its own directory
* Add prefer_bin config, adjust error messages from Worker
Make the config dumper nicer. It's human text now
* Bump version to 1.28_04. Logfile config in environment overrides config
* Fix debugging statements in setup_logging to refer to the right variable
* Don't set defaults for the log4perl config file
* Support the MYCPAN_LOG4PERL_FILE and MYCPAN_LOGLEVEL variables

$application->{argv} is an array reference, dereference

if config has no backpan_dir option then it always was set to
'ARRAY(...)' instead of cwd()
* Add the look_in_cwd_and_lib technique - don't anyone else use it though

* for Queue.pm, I wasn't using a platform specific paths
to check if a dist was under authors/id/./../..
Total rook mistake.
* organize the dists in the first directory in backpan_dirs
* Pass through any environment variables starting with DPAN_ or MYCPAN_
* Refactor the bits to search directories for .pm files
* Set the Log4perl config via MYCPAN_LOG4PERL_FILE
* Restore 15 second alarm time. Just make everyone handle it through a config
* bump to dev version for next dev cycle
* Set Archive::Extract DEBUG and WARN vars by log level
* I was calling guess_primary_package without args, so it wasn't doing anything
* Add more heuristics to guess primary package names (private packages)

Added the resources to the META.yml.

They contain the github homepage and the repository URL.

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>
* fix _path_parts in Queue.pm, which was using the wrong argument for the last bit

Fixed a typo in a comment.

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>

pod fixes

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>

ignore "~" temp files in git and manifest

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>
* Update version to 1.25 to sync with DPAN stuff
ignore "~" temp files in git and manifest

Fixed a regression - get_config is no longer a method of App::Indexer.

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/briandfoy/mycpan-indexer into bdfoy/master

::Dispatch:: to ::Dispatcher:: in the example configs.

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>

fix name in pod

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/briandfoy/mycpan-indexer into bdfoy/master
* Try to guess the primary package based on file name
* Keep track of weird dists that I have to handle
* Add Component, Coordinator, and Notes to MANIFEST
* bump to a release version, 1.24, so MyCPAN::App::DPAN can depend on it for CPAN Testers
* Fix mock in base.t to have the right structure
* Take out the get_config tests in backpan.t since that moved to the coordinator
* Update the Tutorial for the Coordinator stuff

* refactor activate() to a series of simple method calls
* Pass any information by storing it in the application object
* Fix Serial.pm for new Notes scheme

* Work out get_config conflict in Coordinator and Indexer

The get_config in Indexer should realyl be init_config and only
called once to install the defaults.

There's a secondary problem about storing a list of dirs
for backpan_dir. ConfigReader::Simple only sets values that
are strings. We'll figure out how to get around that later. For
now we just have to know it's a space separated string and hard-code
around that.

* adjust examples with actual name of methods

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>

s{MD5}{Digest::MD5} as MD5 has been deprecated.

Signed-off-by: brian d foy <brian.d.foy@gmail.com>
s{MD5}{Digest::MD5} as MD5 has been deprecated.

* This is a major reorganization for Notes and Coordinator objects.

+ The components now have a base class and use instances

+ The Notes have their own class.

+ A coordinator class handles communication between all of the
components. It stores the references to each component and
the Notes. There is a lot of delegation and shortcut methods
to cut out some of the clutter.

+ I rearranged a lot of the class names and some of the file
locations. Most notably, the *::Dispatch:: are now *::Dispatcher::*
to make it a noun like the other names. Other changes shouldn't
affect you.
* A few minor fixes to the docs
* Get default config keys through a method, not direct access to hash

Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/briandfoy/mycpan-indexer

Conflicts:
	lib/Indexer.pm
* adjust examples with actual name of methods
* Parallel.pm bought another semicolon just to show off to Serial.pm
* Don't handle SIGINT in Text.pm. We have to handle it higher than that to clean up tempdirs
* Refactored the examine_dist to break out module and test processing
* Get ready to handle SIGINT leaving behind temp dirs.
* turn some prints into log4perl calls
* Fix the error handling in rename during copy_dists_to_authors
* The start of the organize_dists feature
* localize the %ENV before we start stripping it
* Remove Windows line endings from MANIFEST
* Bump version ahead of latest on CPAN (unlike last time
* Update MANIFEST and Makefile.PL for Serial.pm
* Create a serial dispatcher that does no forking
* Get rid of the TextMate project.
* Bump the version - got rid of YAML::Syck
* Don't use both YAML and YAML::Syck. We already have YAML, so just use that
* A couple of typo fixes to Parallel.pm
* The various indexers need the run method from MyCPAN::Indexer, and should call their application-starting method 'activate' instead
* In the interfaces, print the name and version of the indexing class
* The last dev release had a dirty MANIFEST (again)
* The last dev release had a dirty MANIFEST
* separate cleanup and exit, and remove DPAN tests
* Put the call to dist_info return a scalar when I need the unpack_dir
* bump version to 1.17.11 for extra skip stuff
* use the right hash key to get the module version value
* Bump version. This excludes a couple more special packages

Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:briandfoy/mycpan-indexer

Conflicts:

	lib/DPAN.pm

* Store more information about  so we can
do forensics later

When I create the 03modlist.data.gz file, I need to define
the CPAN::Modulelist package and create a data() subroutine
that returns a hash reference. CPAN.pm expects to laod this
file then call that method.
* Ignore Archive::Extract error if we're on Windows

* Hard-code some package names to skip automatically, don't complain about Archive::Extract on Windows

We want to skip some packages. There really isn't a good way to do this
because there is no rule that encapsulates it. You juast have to
know what not to put in 02pacakges. For instance, don't ever index
a package called "main".

Archive::Extract seems to be working just fine in Windows, but it still gives
and error. I'll ignore that error if it is on Windows.
* Ignore Debian file created by cpants_lint.pl

* Check $Notes->{Finished} to see if the interface shuold keep going.

Previously I was checking $Notes->{Left} to see if the interface
should keep going. However, that was computed in the dispatcher
parent process when it launched a child. Consequently, it went
down to zero when it launched the last process even though that
process had not completed. The child process would complete, but
the rest of dpan went on to create the 02packages. That happens
fast enought that the final report doesn't make it into the
processing. Oops.
* ignore the BBEdit project file. It's annoyingly unstable

* Ensure that backpan_dir is an array ref, and set report_dir sub directories correctly

I adjusted the configuration processing to set up more things correctly.
As I've refactored some of the stuff from the messy code, I haven't
followed through with the handling to replace default values when
they are computed from extra-config information.

For instance, I added success_report_subdir and error_report_subdir. The
defaults come from the default report_dir. If you specified a report_dir
in your config, I wasn't recomputing the paths based on that. These are
undocumented settings because I don't want to overwhelm the user with
options.

I also added a hidden and undocumented -c switch to dump the config
after processing and exit.
* change any backslashes to slashes for 02packages

* in dpan, only process the yml files, and only if the dist is still there

Use the new CPAN::PackageDetails, which sorts the package names. The
new App::DPAN puts relative paths in there is it sees the author/id
structure.

I've continued on the work to decide what should show up in 02packages.
There's a catch to this so far: you have to be in the same directory
structure as the original indexing for this to work because it's looking
for the same files. The index results have the full path the dist that
it indexed. If you try it with another directory structure, even the
tiniest bit different in any part of the path, you'll still pick
up the wrong paths from the original index.

That's just a temporary problem though and I haven't decided how
to fix it. For instance, I can just look at the filename, ensure
the dist has the same checksums, then pull out the right info. I
haven't quite decided how I like that.
* add the BBEdit project, which gitignore was ignoring
* Add the test file for defaults inheritance

* Allow DPAN.pm to inherit its parent's defaults; output only existing files

I adjusted DPAN so it can pick up the defaults from its parents. I only
need to set defaults that are different in that case. This also
eliminated a call to tempdir.

I started to work on limiting the stuff that shows up in 02packages
to just the files that are still in the backpan_dir. There might
be results left over from previous runs, but those shouldn't show
up. This stuff doesn't work yet. I think the best shot I have is
looking at the dist_file path, checking that it lives under
backpan_dir, then checking that it still exists.

I also moved the logging setup to after the config setup. I wanted
to configure the init_and_watch time. So, there's a short period
of time where there is no logging. Maybe I can set up basic logging
and then re-init later if I really need to see something sooner.

* Get rid of "meta" as a literal, clean up temp directories

I don't like that "meta" was a special string all over the
place. That name of the directory for reports is now
an undocumented configuration directive.

I added some bits to do cleanup on the way out, including
removing all of the temporary directories. I wish I could
let File::Temp do that, but in odd cases it seems to clean
up some directories too early. Maybe the forked processes
are doing that.
* Fix up final_words to strip path components

* Archive::Extract reports failure when it works, so ignore it

For some reason, Archive::Extract 0.26 on Windows under cygwin
and Starwberry Perl doesn't think it works. extract() returns
false although it works. Instead of checking the return value,
I'll record it and move on as if it worked.

I haven't been able to reproduce the problem though. Maybe it
doesn't have anything to do with tempdirs.
* add time_summary to see who takes the longest

* Subclassable find_modules, better find_dist_dir

find_modules was doing quite a bit of work that DPAN
doesn't care about, so now it takes its task list from
find_module_tasks (much like examine_dist_techniques
and find_module_techniques). DPAN.pm can now put
just what it wants in find_module_tasks and not do
the work whose result it won't use.

find_dist_dir was causing some problems. Some modules
don't extract nicely, so I was using File::Find to
look for something that looked like a dist dir. The
modules that include dist-like directories for testing
were failing because I wasn't looking at the values
I got back. I was using the first result blindly, but
I should really use the shortest path.

examine_dist now records its starting and ending times
so I can do some analysis about who is taking all of
the time.

* Cleanup temp directories and remove temp dir default

Everything seems to work, although I still don't know
what the temp dir problem was.

Bumped the version number.

* Now with extra chdirs and a default temp dir

Things were getting weird with the temp dirs and File::Temp
couldn't figure out where it was. I have no idea what was going
on (maybe it was in a temp dir while it was getting cleaned up?).
Now I act ultra-paranoid to see make sure I know what is
happening.

* make paths absolute, put temp dirs in the current working dir

I ran into a lot of path problems on Windows that didn't show
up elsewhere. I eventually solved these by running the paths
through rel2abs. Also, I create the temporary directories
in the current working directory.

I also needed to fix up the ARGV processing. The command-line
arguments become arguments to run, but getopts needs them to
be in @ARGV. So, for a quick fix, localize @ARGV, then after
getopts changeds it, assign the result back to the original
list. Use that as the backpan_dirs if that is not already
set in the config.

* Make getppid work everywhere.

getppid doesn't work on Windows because it doesn't do it as
separate processes. I'll make it a method and intercept calls
to Windows.

* Get rid of Tk prereq, fix up writing to modules/

The Tk stuff is not a prereq, but you need to install it to
use the Tk interface.

In DPAN.pm, I needed to ensure that the modules/ directory
existed before I tried to write to it, and that everyone
was using the right file paths. This came up when I decided
to index any directories, just not those that already
looked like a CPAN directory.

For some reason, the exporting from File::Find::Closures
isn't working under 5.10, so I'll just use the full
package specification and worry about it later.

* App::DPAN works, but there's a little polish to do

Most of the the MyCPAN::App::DPAN works, along with the
dpan.pl script that uses it. There are still a few indexing
oddities, such as pmtools, but other than that it's time
to test it on Windows.

I changed the App::BackPAN::Indexer to handle the command
line a bit differently. If backpan_dir is not in the config,
it looks at @ARGV. If there is nothing in @ARGV, it uses
the current working directory.

Now, backpan_dir might be a single element or an array
reference. It should always be one thing, but I'm changing
it in the middle here so I have to support the single
element (i.e. not array ref) until I find all the other
places that use it. There is some ugly code to deal with
it being possibly both.

* Queue just looks in backpan_dir, DPAN.pm get docs

The Queue class now just looks in the backpan_dir
configuration. It's up to the application to the
application to populate that through configuration
or defaults. If It's not set, App::BackPAN::Indexer
sets it to @ARGV

I added the docs to the DPAN app. I just need to
make it work now.
* Get rid of CVS tags and re-order changes
* bumped version to next trial release

* Fix the missing UUID problem

* Data::UUID needs to be in the PREREQs, and I have to
get the UUID from $Notes, not the config.

* Applications, configurable pipelines, bug squishing

* The examine_dist and find_modules methods now do their
work by looking for the tasks they should do in
examine_dist_techniques and find_modules_techniques.
This makes it easy to subclass and change the indexing,
as in MyCPAN::Indexer::DPAN.

* The applications in *::App::* can now set their own
defaults. This way you can get around making config
files and using command line arguments.

* Added two new techniques to find module files:
look in META.yml 'provides', or search all of the
subdirs for *.pm. This was important for Term::Readline::Perl

* Fixed various impedence issues where modules need
to join each other.

* Moved the backpan_indexer code to MyCPAN::App::BackPAN::Indexer.
Now the script just calls the run() method in that module.

* Created MyCPAN::App::DPAN as a subclass of  MyCPAN::App::BackPAN::Indexer.
It just calls the run() method, but later on it should auto-configure
some of the stuff.
* Bump to a release version so I can install from a normal CPAN

* Archive::Extract does not propagate it's $WARN setting to
Archive::Tar's $WARN. I've patched that and submitted rt.cpan.org #40472
to get a fix into Archive::Tar. Even though some things untar
just fine, Archive::Tar likes to complain. Go figure.

* Don't require these configuration directives:
	copy_bad_dists
	retry_errors
	indexer_class

* Added a new() to Indexer so I can make objects in a
subclassable way. There's a bit more work there, but
it's a start.

* All of the logging routines now use Log4perl's OO
interface, so I found a few hold-outs from the
conversion from the functional interface.

* Add the dist name to the logging message whenever I
can. This helps when watching the logs as several
processes run at the same time. Also, removed the
PID from the message strings---handle that in a
Log4perl conversion pattern

* In Queue, added a filter to not return files ending
in data.gz or txt.gz. This way I can ignore any of the
PAUSE files without having to start at a lower directory.

* [get_task] If an indexing attempt fails, try to recover
so I still get a report. Every attempt should have some
sort of report for later inspection.

* Only use one process at a time to index Andy Armstrong's stuff. Running
things in parallel seems to be losing reports.

* added some example config files for specific tasks so I don't
have to modify them in demonstrations

* Fixed Curses.pm so that it retuned from do_interface when it
is done

* Added the -f and -i options to backpan_indexer.pl so I can
change the config and log4perl files on the command line. Huh,
that -i should be a -l for log I think.
Eric Wilhelm's script to look for Module::Build
* Added Eric Wilhelm's META.yml stats message

* odd scripts I have lying around.

dh_make_perl has the stuff that the linux people use to figure out
licensing automatically.

test_uses.pl goes through the indexer reports and counts test
modules.

the other scripts test parallelism.
* unlink file when someone calls the reporter

* It looks like the concurrency problem is one of file paths. I'm
not creating the files where I think I am, so they are probably
in the temp dir, which disappears.

* I don't know why I can't DBM::Deep or dbmopen to do the right
thing. There shouldn't be a problem with concurrency, but there
is.

* Added *::Reporter::Text to do simple text reporting without any
fancy interface

* Still working on TestCensus. My previous try was stupid: all the
info was in the children, but I wanted it in the parent. I could do
all that wacky perlipc stuff, but instead I'll have the children
write to a DBM::Deep file and see how that works out.
* Added *::Interface::Text which just uses print() to do its work

* Implementing the base reporter class; this gets me to where I am
right now, but with a pluggable report mechanism.

* The goal is to get the TestCensus module working so it can go
through all of the distributions and record the test modules
used.

* refactored the component loading in backpan_indexer.pl since
I've cleaned up the return values from the method calls. Each
method sets a value in $Notes, so I don't care about the return
value.
* move prereq test to release time

* Updating the versions on all modules using the PPI::App::ppi_version
tool. Now I'll keep all of the modules aligned with the same version
number, and version numbers will apply to releases, not intermediate
steps to a release.

* Removed several of the experimental scripts dealing with interfaces.
All that good stuff moved into Tk.pm or Curses.pm.
* Adding version to all of the modules

* Fixed the problem of the extra processes sticking round in the
process list. Previously I was checking $Notes->{Left} to see if
I should do something in the interface callback. That value went
down to zero once the work was passed out but while processes
were still running. Since it was zero, I didn't do anything in
the interface_callback. Now, if $Notes->{Left} is zero, I
call Parallel::ForkManager's wait_all_children and return. That
cleans up any remaining processes.

* Fixed the bits that do the headers for the process tracking and the
errors windows.

* There is still some odd stuff with numbering the processes.

* Fixed the progress bar. It's all a matter of doing the math right
and remembering that division happens before addition. :)

* Setting the term type to vt525 seems to do everything right, but
now I have to deal with some problems with using the right window
names in all the curses calls.

* The Curses stuff seems to work under term="ansi", but that's pretty
ugly in vi where my arrow keys don't work. What term type should I be
using?

* First pass at a Curses interface. It's not working out too
well though. When I update the values everything goes wacky.
* Add insructions to the sample configuration file
* ignore the config file for backpan_indexer.pl

* Move the sample configuration file to another name so
git isn't tracking it and I can mess with the real
configuration file.

* Fix the problem of the floating Label widgets. I didn't
set the right pack() things in their frame. Now I have.

* Add ::NullTester to Makefile.PL

* Using ::NullTester as the queue class. Since there is nothing
to process, the interface comes up but doesn't do anything.
Neat! I don't have to null out the other components either.

* I don't need this script. If I've done the design well,
I should be able to plug in null components so I don't have
to do anything else to test each bit.

* Working on creating null classes for each of the components
so I can do interface testing. This is also cleaning up
::Tutorial and making the API consistent.

* ::Queue and ::Worker now change $Notes inside their methods
instead of returning the value. This makes them more like the
methods in the other components.

* Everything works again.

* Some things that are still broken:
	+ the look of the interface. How to get those labels to align?
	+ the last processes stay in the window when everything is
	finished. Hmmm.
	+ some odd warnings remain

* Removed some debugging output in backpan_indexer.pl

* Added a Tutorial.pm that explains the different parts

* Moved the interface_callback creator into Parallel.pm, which
also does more of its own configuration.

* I've fixed the odd child problem where it looked like each
child was trying to start new jobs. I'm not sure what fixed
the problem, but I wasn't passing $Notes to add_run_info. Once
I fixed that the problem disappeeared. Good enough for me.

* Make sure the temp_dir path exists before I start to
do aything

* The Worker class needed to know where catfile came from.

* I moved the BEGIN block loading Parallel::ForkManager to
the top of the file thinking it needed to be loaded earlier.
Somehow I think the child processes are having their exit
overloaded again. Not sure....

* The interface is mostly working, but the interface callback stuff
isn't doing something right.

* Moving around the initialization in $Notes (and incurring some
debt there), but I'll figure that out later. I thought I was being
clever moving that out of backpan_indexer.pl, but it's coming back.

* Adjusting the interface just a little.

* Set up some keys in $Notes for child tracking, and set Threads so
the interface class knows how many rows to make

* I think I have all of the bits connected, but there are still some
places I need to fix. Someone needs to ensure that $Notes (formerly
$Vars) has the right keys for the Tk interface.

* Moved the child_task bits to its own class, which you now
set in teh configuration with the worker_class directive.

* Moving lots of things around so each bit gets its
own subclass. I'm trying to decouple all of this as
much as possible, but everyone at least has to respect
interfaces between each bit

* I've pulled out the bits to make the list of dists to
process and put them in MyCPAN::Indexer::Queue. Now anyone
can write the code to generate the list. To use another
module, put it in the configuration file as the value
for queue_class:

	queue_class MyCPAN::Indexer::Queue

That class has to implement a get_queue() method that returns
an array reference of file paths.
* Final cleanups to get it running as part of backpan_indexer
* tk-ified the indexer, but it's not working yet

* Remove the debugging code from steak.pl, and tell the Config
to look in my MINICPAN.

* Now handles an external queue of things to process. This is
probably one or two steps away from being in the backpan
indexer.

* Changed the subroutine names from get_ to make_ - they
aren't really getting anything since they add directly
to the data structure.
* Put the repeat callback code into its own sub.

* Moved the forking code to a subroutine and added the
forker object o $Vars

* Moved the callback to give to Tk's repeat into $Vars
too.

* Abstract the child_task code so the code reference I pass to
do_tk_stuff doesn't hard code it.

* Separated the Tk code from the forking code (steak.pl).

* Added the process handling to the recent processes list. Now
the process is removed when it returns.

* Tuning the refresh time on the Tk repeat call. Sometimes the
process appears to hang but I think that's Parallel::ForkManager
getting stuck in start() when it is trying to launch a new process.

* Now I have it hooked up to Parallel::ForkManager, which I had to
modify a bit to work with Tk. IF you're using Tk, the real exit is
CORE::exit.

The next bit is to fix the processing queue to remove the finished
jobs.
* Added elapsed time and progress bar
* Starting to hook up the variables to the entries

* I think I have all of the interface bits in the right
place and how I want them. The next step is to hook it
up to something that spits out numbers.
* I'm in the middle of creating the Tk interface
* Experimenting with a curses reporting interface
* just changing config values for testing

* The undef manifest problem came back, and I still don't know what it
is causing it. Making a copy of the array seems to work.

* For some reason, adding the list of file in MANIFEST to dist_info
wasn't working. It got the right number of files, but all the
values in the YAML were undef. I'm not sure why it now works, but
moving a coupel lines around did the trick.

* Use Parallel::ForkManager to run jobs in parallel.

* Running this over my own BackPAN dir (B/BD/BDFOY) dropped the
run time from about 1200 seconds to about 900 seconds if I set
the number of jobs at 4.

* Add bits to guess the file MIME type and the line
count signature

* Make the prereq.t test work - one of the files in my .cpan
directory was owned by root and it was a deal killer for
CPAN.pm starting up.

* Added the missing prereqs to Makefile.PL
* auto find scripts in the compile test
* add a test to check that scripts compile

* Back to doing a real run

* Test that scripts can compile

* Fix the bugs related to choosing indexer class

* Scrub the environment at the start of a run

* Make indexer_class work. People can now use
whatever indexer they like

* Added more run information to each, including
	+ Make a UUID for every invocation of backpan_indexer.pl
	+ record perl and system info
	+ add config keys for contact and system id so I can have user
	generated tags for runs
	+ initial bits to make indexing class configurable
	+ record the contents of %ENV too

* record the MD5 digest of the dist file
* record perl version and OS info about the run

* Find all the test files and get their information.

* For the modules and test files, use Module::Extract::Use to see
which modules they require.

* cheange the file_info key to module_info. Now that I collect the
stats for the stuff in MANIFEST and in blib, I can also see if
the module changed when it went into blib.

* And, since I now collect file stats for all of the files
in MANIFEST, I should try to identify which file are Perl
scripts.

* In run() I do need to shift off the class name after all!
That foreach uses @_, so class shouldn't be in there.

* Added the TRACE call to each subroutine

* refactored get_module_info to put the file meta-data in
get_file_info. I'll also collect the file info for everything
in MANIFEST.

* If the archive type is gz even though the archive is tgz, Archive::Extract
is not going to return an error because it can still ungzip it. So, even
if Archive::Etract thinks it got the right thing, try tgz anyway.

Maybe I should always set the type. Most everything is a tgz, and there
are only a couple hundred zip files.

Working on the case where the dist is a different archive than
what it claims. Netscape-Bookmarks-2.1491D0.gz ends with just
.gz, but is really a tar archive too.

The plan is to let Archive::Extract guess on its own, and if
that doesn't work, try it with the hint that it is a tar.gz.

* Copy bad dists if the copy_bad_dists value is set in the config
file. The value should be the directory to copy the bad dists too.
It will not create the directory though.

* If retry_errors is true in the config, erase all the error
output in meta_errors. That way those dists get processed
again.

* Added tracing to some methods

* examine() now calls find_modules() instead of run_build_file().
That way, find_modules can try several things to get the list
of modules. examine also doesn't handle collecting the file
info for the modules anymore.
* use colored levels in log output

* Refactored stuff in run() into examine().

* In examine, the list of methods to go through also says
whethere a failure should be fatal. For instance, not
every idst has a META.yml, so parsing that file would
fail. The run shouldn't fail just for that.

* Refactored the run() method in Indexer.pm to  handle
everything in the same way.

* Lots of small moves to make the debugging output come
out easier to read and at the right time.

* Added docs to MyCPAN::Indexer

* Cleaned up most of the methods in MyCPAN::Indexer

* the alarm threshold is now configurable

Who woulda thunk that File::Basename throws exceptions? IF you don't pass
something to dirname, file_parse croaks. Why can't people just return nothing?

* Acme-Bushisms-0.01 wasn't a flat structure, so I had to look for the
MANIFEST is sub dirs (finding it in Acme/Bushisms). In Indexer.pm I
separated the bits where I unpack the dist from where I find the dist
dir.

* I ran into a problem with the current working directory, too. Once
I start using the File::Temp stuff, I can't assume that I'm in any
particular directory. So, anything that expects to work from the
unpack_dir should get the unpack_dir from the dist_info, not
assuming it's also cwd(). This caused some headaches with the new
find_dist_dir method.

* I also added run_error as something to add to the report. If I'm
going to bail out, put something in there so I know what happened.

* Now I can try indexing a single distribution by specifying
it on the command line. If there are arguments, use those
as the list to index. If there are no arguments, look in
the config to find the directory which has the dists.
Use Distribution::Guess::System. It's broken right now.
The beginning of a script to index BackPAN

readme:
== Welcome to my newbie Blog System in Rails, this is a project for my university monography. 
I'm a newbie in Rails, Object-Oriented Programming and also Web-Programming, I work as a COBOL Mainframe programmer, completely different area. 
I just started in this new PC/WEB area, and I'm sure that's the future, I hope get some help here.

================================================================================================================

Basically my idea is something like this (consider as a textual class diagram please):
=> User login:string name:string email:string crypted_password:string salt:string image:binary created_at:datetime updated_at:datetime remember_token:string remember_token_expires_at:datetime
-Want use Restful_Authentication plugin here, also upload a picture for the user

=> Blog name:string address:string description:text icon:binary template_id:references
-Icon to be used as Favicon in the blog, also use some CSS already build like Zen Garden's CSS

=> BlogUser blog_id:references user_id:references level:integer
-Level for the user (Integer 1 byte):
9 - System Owner
8 - Power Admin
7 - Admin
6 - Moderator ( 9 to 6 will user blog_id = 0 because they have to control every blog and every user, maybe to avoid forbidden stuff like pornography or piracy or spam)
5 - reserved for the future
4 - Blog Owner 
3 - Blog Post Member
2 - Banished from Blog (maybe for spammers)
1 - Banished from system (also using blog_id = 0)
-Users without level can only comment, only logged users could comment

=> Template name:string css:string
-Built CSS just for the blogs

=> Post blog_id:references user_id:references title:string body:text

=> Category name:string

=> CategoryPost category_id:references post_id:references

=> Comment post_id:references user_id:references body:text

================================================================================================================

Well that's the idea, I hope you help me 8D

Using the gems:
-RMagick
-will_paginate
until now

Using the plugins:
-restful_authentication
until now too

Luiz Biagi 
Rails Beginner
